bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 1, 1929

div1.p: Carter and Frost spend Christmas working on bibliographical references for the History of Yellow Fever manuscript. Carter renews her borrowing privileges at the Library of Congress so that she and Brown can keep working efficiently together.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 1, 1929
div1.opener:
Book,
Misel.
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland.
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 1, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
A happy New Year to you and all manner of good therein both
for yourself and the International Health Division!

Your very kind letter of December 22, 1928, was forwarded to me
in Baltimore, whither I went the Sunday before Xmas to work with
Dr. Frost on Father's MS. I looked a good deal like an immigrant
when I set out with my literary impedimenta (four heavy pieces of baggage, one of which was a
huge two handled basket full of reference books, which, by the way,
Dr. Frost was very glad to see).

Monday (Xmas Eve) I worked mainly by myself, as Dr. Frost was
busy all morning with other things.

Wednesday, Dec. 26th. Dr. Frost and I worked from about 9 A. M.
to 5.30 P. M. and were both “all in” when we stopped. However, we
got a lot done and agreed on work that I could do over here, in
Washington, until we could get together again, our contemplated
schedule for working until after New Years Day having been knocked
to pieces by conferences, which Dr. Frost has to attend, etc. This
mainly on account of the flu situation.

Thursday then, I decided had best see me back in Washington,
the more so as Mrs. Frost and her little girl both developed flu
while I was there, one on Xmas night, the other 24 hours later. Of
course, had Dr. Frost had any more time to give me, I should have
moved to an hotel. As it was, however, I began sorting out the mater-
ial Dr. Frost wished me to take back with me at 6.15 A. M. and got
through in time to catch the 4.16 home. Mrs. Frost was urgent that
that
-2-
I leave the house in the morning lest I contract the flu, but I had
already been exposed to it and the extra chance involved in my delay
in order to get the bibliographic and library cards Frost wanted me
to take from his files was not to be compared with the advantage of
having the material here for Miss Brown to work on if I did get sick.
We had a “night session” last week and talked things over (mainly in
regard to getting the bibliographic cards in a form in which Dr. Frost feels he can
handle them more quickly and in copying, and sending back to his files
the accompanying library cards. Miss Brown has already done quite a
lot of work on the library cards since my return from Baltimore.

Yesterday, I had to spend a good deal of time in getting my
library priveleges renewed at the Congressional Library, they expiring
December 31, 1928. This I did, because while most of the work Dr.
Frost now wishes me to do can be best done at my apartment, it is a
necessity to have the privelege of taking books home for this work, and
a great convenience (practically a necessity) to keep my desk, table
and reference books at the Library of Congress, in order that Miss
Brown be able to work there out of hours and that the reference books
be readily available. Also, I shall need to go there myself from
time to time.

Miss Brown and I are both very grateful for your good wishes and
kind expressions of appreciation about the work on the bibliography.
We have worked! We appreciate also what you said about taking off
time during the holidays, but--frankly--I'm afraid to stop work save
just long enough to get sufficiently rested to go back to it--i. e.
late afternoons and sometimes at night. There is too much flu around
for me to put off work for recreation. However, even should I contract
it--which I most earnestly hope I won't!--it wouldn't be half so bad
as it was last year: the bulk of the work is done now and Miss Brown
although at considerable inconvenience to herself, could
co-operate
-3-
with Dr. Frost in the remaining work. However, “here's hoping” I
don'twont get it--at least until I have a bound copy of the book to
read during my convalescence!

Once more, with heartfelt good wishes to you all, at home and
overseas, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
